reviewText:
i have played olliolli 2 before on the ps4. so i know what i am getting. but so happy its on WIN/MAC/LINUX.

handles great, tight controls and the gameplay is stepped up a notch because manuals/reverts are in. so combos are huge.
the soundtrack is brilliant. great and well chosen music, perfect for olliolli.
a perfectly balanced game, that really does make you wonder if your gamepad will last the night from retry after retry to get the highest scores

one thing i can say on a bad note is that the optimisation seems to be a bit slow. unlike olliolli 1 which was stupidly fast, there seems be some slow down here. it may be because of the port [because it feels like one, if not fair enough]. but i will leave that up to updates in future and hope it gets addressed.

all in all, a great product, sequel and tons of fun. well worth it. you should buy it

rating: solid

-*UPDATED ADDITION REGARDING SLOW DOWN*-
i did actually turn down the resolution in video settings, and that has really made a difference to what it should be like. so maybe try that if slow down is a problem

reviewText:
Awesome skateboarding game that is a nice challenge, has good controls and will keep you laughing. I was a big fan of the SKATE series and this is pretty much a 2d/indie version of SKATE.

If you want gameplay that is a nice challenge, enjoy skateboarding or just want an overall fun game give this one a try! You will be doing all kinds of crazy tricks for hours on end. The maps are very well designed levels and the game is quite addicting!

This game will keep you coming back for more and more trying to beat hard levels and trying to improve scores. The game also has been running well to, no crashes, no fps issues, no gamebreaking bugs,etc..

Olli! Olli! Olli! Olli!

reviewText:
What the first OlliOlli game did well in, this sequel made better.

While it's possible to play on keyboard, you may find yourself in a better position with a controller, as pulling off tricks with the analog feels easy to do when you first play it. There are also new tricks to do to further your scoring potentail that wasn't there in first game: Manuals, Reverts and Switch-Grinding. This means you can score even harder than you imagined compared to the first game.

In the same fashion of the first game, there are levels with challenges for you to clear to unlock Pro mode, which is the harder variation of that stages. Clearing Pro mode will unlock RAD mode, which is skating flawlessly or eat dirt for not nailing everything perfectly. Safe to say it's not for the faint of heart or those who never experence having sore thumbs for gaming hard.

For those that look to boast their scoring abilites after handling what the game has to offer, look no further to Spot challenges and the Daily Grind that has online leaderboards. You can also play locally with up to 4 buds in a split-screen Combo rush mode, which is a nice plus to what the game already has.

OlliOlli2 is a good step up from the original, worth looking into if you're interested.

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Great, responsive controls
+Lots of content
+Looks great
+Few glitches (other than some clipping with death animations that are mentioned below)
+Very difficult, yet rewarding enough to keep you going
+Very addictive
+ Has free-play mode for all levels

Cons:
- $17 might be a little bit much to ask for a 2d side-scrolling game, but value isn't really a concern if you end up liking the game and pumping hours upon hours into it (like I am likely to do)
- Death animations are hilarious the first few times but are ultimately on the glitchy side with some clipping, and obvious disregard of physics, although intentional, I would've prefered somehting a little less over-the-top
- Menu controls on the controller are more than a little finicky
- No 21:9 support (although, it doesn't crop like some games, it just adds black bars on the side, but it would've been really useful in a side-scroller like this to have that kind of support, enven if my high scores didn't count)

Bottom Line:
As someone who was a huge fanboy for the Skate series on Playstation, and a huge advocate for sports games, seeing another skateboarding game on PC is refreshing, even if it's quite a lot different looking than Skate. But removing that third dimension, they still managed to keep the element of difficulty in this game while keeping it very simple.
This is a simply addictive skateboard game that is a must-buy for anyone who liked Super Hexagon, Skate, or the Tony Hawk games, and I would still recomend it to anyone else who is looking for a simple game that's easy to learn and run, but addictive and difficult enough to keep you angrily fascinated enough to keep playing.

reviewText:
The gameplay has been vastly improved upon the original OlliOlli, it's more responsive and the addition of manual and reverts makes the game deeper, more challenging, and more fun.
The graphics have also been improved quite a lot.
A new multiplayer mode is cool, although it is only splitscreen 4-way (even if you're just 2 players) on your monitor, an online multi would have been awesome.
The soundtrack is still great, but it might be the only point where the first one was better. There are still some fantastic songs on this one, but a couple of them are a bit forgettable, and I'm missing a couple of the best ones from the original. Gonna look into a way to mod" them into this version if possible.

For newcomers

reviewText: Even better than first one!\nOlliOlli2: Welcome to Olliwood is a hard as hell sidescroll arcade skate game, which is probably the best skate" game you can get on Steam.\nI'm a huge fan of the first one aswell
date:
but in my opinion the developers managed to make a great game even better.
Here's why:

The positive :

+  An outstanding soundtrack.

The first one had a great soundtrack
recommended: too and OlliOlli2 doesn't disappoint in the slightest with it's choice of music. It's a mixture of electronica
hoursPlayed:
glitch & and hiphop (artists like CidRim or Kyle Cook) and does just fit so well to game. One of the reasons I like that game so much!

+  Optimized Gameplay.

What makes OlliOlli2 such a great successor is the fact that they added plenty of new mechanics which make the game for one part more difficult but also way more entertaining. Now it is possible to get even bigger combos due to the new manuals and reverts. Also they added a bunch of new tricks (Double Treflip
voteText: Darkslide and others) and you're now allowed to change your trick while grinding (f.e. from Nosegrind to Crailslide). This makes the gameplay just so much more fun
helpfulPercent:
as you have way more options to finish a level. The tricks are done similar to the game Skate by using the leftstick to perform different moves.

+  Fixed the old problems.

Another positive aspect is the overall more polished presentation and more responsive controls. While still retaining the retro look they also managed to make game look better overall. Also in the first part it sometimes felt like some controls weren't executed by the game (resulting in starting all over). Roll7 did a good job in fixing some minor issues.
Plus
votesHelpful: the new levels look pretty great and have (especially in the later pro levels) a really nice level design. I sometimes had problems distinguishing some objects and obstacles in the first one
votesTotal:
now everything is quite good to see.

+  Lots of content for a reasonable price.

The game isn't that expensive and for a really nice price you get a lot of content. You basically have 5 levels per world and 5 challenges per level. It takes a while to beat everything (took me around 8 hours for the amateur challenges)
votesFunny: also you have lots of achievements and a nice feature called daily grind where you can play a level and compare you points on a worldwide leaderboard.\nOh
commentsCount: and there is an extra "spot" per level you have to skate in one combo
column16:
which also will be visible on a leaderboard.

The neutral :

~  Could've added more new gameplay features

I generelly like everything they added but I feel like they easily could add even more
column18:
real Lateflips (can only be done with a trick combo f.e. Hardflip-LateShuvIt) and Flatlandtricks while manualing. I guess they keep that for another sequel.

~  Hard as hell!

I generelly don't see it as really flaw (I actually like it
column19:
you have quite a high skill ceiling) but it should be mentioned that it is a really difficult game and for some people maybe a lil bit too difficult.


The negative :

-  Some minor flaws

I'm having a hard time finding anything bad
column20: but there are some minor flaws I should mention. For example the game occasionally freezes for 2-3 seconds

Overall impression :

I absolutely recommend this game if you're into arcade and/or sidescrolling games! It's basically a mixture of games like SuperMeatBoy and Skate.
The second part does everything the first did and even more and better

reviewText:
I know i haven't played this game very much yet, mainly because i did not have a controller before and playing this game with a keyboard is quite difficult.
Also it takes more time to get used to all the buttons required to do tricks, land them, grind etc.
So, today i bought a controller, which isn't anything fancy (pricetag was about 15€ = 18$), and it works just fine with OlliOlli2.
Also i beat my first level highscore on second try, which took like 20 tries on keyboard...
yeah, playing this game with a controller is that much easier and you get used to controls much faster and in comparison i have very little experience playing with controllers.
So if you get this game, get a controller also because you will have hard time trying to learn how to play this game properly with a keyboard.
The controller which i bought is Giotek VX-1 (works on PC/PS3) and i can play this game just fine with it, only problem that this controller has, is that X,Y,A,B have been replaced with some weird ♥♥♥ dots, but i got used to those buttons quite quickly.

Pros:
- Good, in-depth tutorial
- Multiple levels and gamemodes
- Dozens of different tricks and over a dozen of different grind styles
- Leaderboards, if you want to compete with other players
- Nice, fitting in-game music

Cons:
- Hard to play with keyboard, get a controller instead, as i explained up there.
- Can make you ragequit if you play with a keyboard.

Not pro or con:
- This game is quite unforgiving, one example is that if you jump over a staircase
and you fail the landing, you fall and you have to restart the level. Although this teaches you how to play.
-------------------------------------------------------
Please, get a controller, just for your own sake.

reviewText: You don't even have to be into skateboarding to seriously enjoy this game
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Skateboarding and videogames go together like peanut butter and jelly.  Just like the Tony Hawk and Skate games left their mark on the industry so too did OlliOlli.  Although the sequel may not be revolutionary it does are great job of capitalizing on what made the first game great while simultaneously improving itself in almost every aspect.  New stages, tricks, and challenges will make this second installment a worthwhile play for those who have already finished the first game.  If you're new to the series don't worry, excellent tutorials will catch you up to speed real fast.

OlliOlli is a fast-paced, side-scrolling, skateboarding extravaganza.  Those who played Skate will feel right as home as this games main tool for tricks is the analog stick.  By flicking the analog stick you can jump up in the air and perform various flip tricks.  You'll also need to hold down the analog stick right before hitting a rail to grind.  To land any other tricks you'll need to tap the A (or X) button right before landing.  As you proceed father into the game you'll need to be able to quickly transition back and forth between rails and the surface in mere seconds.  Its a thrilling experience that requires you to find the right rhythm to flow smoothly through each stage.

The atmosphere in OlliOlli 2 is incredible and the art is gorgeous.  The game has a very slick, colorful, presentation..  Although it clearly resembles the original, this time around the art is much cleaner and a lot less pixalated.  Each location offers a unique theme from the jungle, to the old west, the carnival, and beyond.  The highlight however is the soundtrack.  A wonderful selection of pulsing electronic music is bound to put you in a trance as you play.  The best part about the music in this game is that it keeps playing continuously, even as you reset a stage or open up various menus.

The most notable change to this sequel is the new tricks, specifically manuals.  Just like manuals revolutionized the second Tony Hawk game so too do they this game.  The ability to manual coincidentally lets you combo your tricks trough the entirety of each level.  This is especially import for the Spot mode which only let you perform one combo per stage.  Manuals are pretty easy to do so if you really want to achieve a high-school you'll need to combine them with two of the other new tricks, grind-switches and reverts.  Grind-switches let you mix things up on long grinds while reverts let you switch your stance as you land a trick.

This is clearly an enjoyable title in many ways.  The gameplay is very smooth and rewarding while the soundtrack is exciting and motivating.  That all being said this really isn't that drastically different from the first game.  If you played the original OlliOlli you can pretty much expect more of what that game offered.  The new stages and tricks, along with a magnificent new soundtrack, add quite a bit of value and incentive for picking up this game.  Whether you played the first one or not it, definitely check this one out.  OlliOlli offers a thrilling experience for gamers and skaters alike.

reviewText:
OlliOlli 2 is a very satisfying and fun skating game.
A Gameplay & Review video showcasing the features I'm about to talk about:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-FWXs_TGt_8
The controls are very tight, and it's simple enough to perform different tricks. Although, it takes a bit more effort to string all of them together in a long combo. However, when you get good at the game and manage to do the entire level in one long combo, the game is incredibly satisfying. Stuff like that feels very rewarding.
The trick system is actually decently complex with the amount of stuff you can do.

There's a wide variety of different levels, each containing cool new props and sights to see, which keeps the game fresh.
The game also has a lot of fun modes, including splitscreen tournaments, and daily challenges where you have once chance to get as many points as possible in a unique map created just for that day.

Overall, if you're into skating in any way, give the game a try!

reviewText:
I never played the first game and only picked this up on a whim during a summer sale.

I thought this would be a great party game to play local co-op however due to the numerous issues I've had with controller detection, button latency, and incorrect button registration, it's practically unplayable. In addition, the game will often lag for me during the music transitions which can ruin otherwise excellent runs. I really can't understand the transition lag as I'm running this on an i7-4790k and GTX 970.

The controls feel rather un-intuitive which normally wouldn't be an issue except that you apparently can't remap the controls. What's most bizarre to me is the fact that something as simple as a rumble setting, which the game does have, is not within the game's menu's but requires you to add a -norumble line to the execution path.

I'm guessing this game was made with very specific intentions when it comes to how it's played, thus the option to control any way you'd like is not available.

Personally, I can't recommend this game at it's full price ($15 currently)

reviewText:
I loved the first OlliOlli. Tight controls, no lag, and fantastic flow. OlliOlli 2 is lacking these elements.

I got pretty good at the first one, but in this sequel I'm having major difficulty landing tricks, doing combos and executing grinds. It's just not responsive. Some times it's so bad that I try to do a 3-key combo, 2 of the keys execute, I don't succesfully land, and then the 3rd key I pushed starts executing the next trick.

Grinds in the first game were super fun to do. You'd practically magnetize to rails as long as you were above them. Now you have to be accurate like landing a trick normally. I'd normally be okay with increasing the difficulty, but this just ruins the flow of gameplay.

Also, this game sadly falls into the ever-expanding category of games with Retro-Like Graphics that take a ton of system resources to run".

In conclusion: I'm so disappointed."
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Overall the game is fun, soundtrack is good and look OK for the type of game. There are however glitches here an there and the controls feel somewhat off with my non-xbox controller (could be my controller, could be the game). It's still unclear to me when exactly to “plant” a trick, the momentum feels random most of the time. Also, try to ride down some small stairs without jumping/tricks and try to land, it's impossible to do this right/not-sloppy. Grinding is a big part of the game and especially when you just started playing the game it's unclear whether an object is grindable or not. So you don't know if your just missing the hotspot or you cannot grind it. This is very frustrating. I still like playing the game but in my opinion it's not worth the €14,- and I wish I would have waited a while longer for a discount or something. Cheers.

reviewText: It's a precision platformer where you go really fast. It has a Street Fighter-like combo system, but you rack up points instead of damage, and you're trying really hard to not hurt the little guy instead of beating someone up. It has the constant silly deaths of I Wanna Be The Guy, but with better art and less crashing.\n\n50 levels spread across 5 worlds and 2 tiers of difficulty, each level has 5 badges for meeting certain challenges on the level. One is always to get a certain score, one for getting a certain size combo, and three that make increasingly absurd demands on your dexterity and concentration. As I've gone from struggling to complete world 1 to being able to speed-run through half the game, I have kept running into challenges that make me say what? That's possible? How?" -- and I am still hitting them!"

reviewText:
I just want to say ahead of this review I love the idea of the game, I love the graphics and the indie feel of it. I feel alot of love was put into the idea espcially after checking out the tricktionary and some of the features added into this.

But the biggest complaint I have about this game is the controls, it's so frustratingly bad i couldn't stand more then 10 mins of this game.  I have put thousands of hours into games like Skate, Tony Hawk franchise, and even older the old snowboarder games like Cool Boarders on playstation.  I just feel like this games controls are way to frustrating and they defy common sense.  I think it would have been alot cooler to have it be close to the Tony hawk pro skater franchise in its control scheme, have one button that lets you push and pop the board and have other buttons to do those tricks and then use the analog stick to adjust the land.  Instead of this wonky ♥♥♥ shit where you have to press a button before your board hits the ground with one hand if your using keyboard and the other hand is getting used to doing the tricks.  Its just awkward the way they set it up.

You can remap the controls sure, but that doesnt remap the way they have it set up, because they have push/land on one button so it doesn't actually change anything.

I personally can't recommend this game until a mod comes out to change the control scheme, or the devs add in a way to change the control scheme and that's sad because I really love the idea of this game and I see it has massive potential as an indie game and as a skateboard game on the pc.

reviewText:
Take The Impossible Game and splice it with Tony Hawks Pro Skater 2 and you'd have something like this. OlliOlli2: Welcome to Olliwood features five different campaigns, each with five missions. Each mission has five challenges, which when completed, unlocks the Pro varient of that mission. Once all five chalenges in Pro mode are beaten across the entire game, Rad mode is unlocked. Obviously there are alot of unlockables and plenty of content to keep you wanting more. They even have split screen multiplayer for up to four players so you can share the excitement with friends. However, there are some things excluded from this title that seems kinda....off.
1.) no skater customization: Granted he is a pixelated character with no voice and you barely spend anytime looking at him it would be nice to change his appearance or the look of the skateboard.
2.) No map creator: It wouldn't be so bad if this game didn't scream for it. I could imagine downloading hundreds of fan-made maps that are fun and or difficult.

Still earns a rating of 9/10 from me

reviewText:
I wasn't really huge on the first game.  While it was fun, it also felt bland and didn't entirely grab my attention.

OlliOlli 2 is so much better.  It feels so much more smooth, the levels feel more lively, the new art style is great, the animations are fantastic, and of course, the additions of manuals, reverts, and other awesome tricks are great too.

I definitely recommend this, especially if you're a fan of skating games.  Controls are similar to the flick style of the Skate games but the general gameplay feels like THPS where you're always trying to make awesome combos.  Even if you didn't really like the first OlliOlli I recommend this because it basically fixed all of the aspects that I disliked from the previous game.

The only complaint is that there isn't any sort of calibration mode.  Because of this, it's somewhat difficult for me to play on my TV since it has a bit of input delay, but on my monitor it's completely fine and I'm sure it'll be fine on your monitor too.

reviewText:
OlliOlli2 is an awesome arcade game,
with simple basis but complex advanced techniques,
so you can have a lot of fun  with any skill level,
by trying to finish a level, or doing a level-long combo
to reach the world record.

Concretely, the game is a 2D skating game, I think you noticed it,
but what the screenshots and the trailer don't show you,
is that this game has a particular gameplay.

You can enter tricks with the left stick, and do spins or special tricks
with the triggers of your pad (pad game,  almost unplayable on keyboard).
but you need, when landing your tricks,
to press the A (or cross)  button before hitting the floor to validate your trick.
(and also not slam your head on the asphalt)

and this is a really particular gameplay mechanic,
so you will need a little bit time to get used with it.

bit by bit, you will try more advanced tricks,
and pretty insane techniques to do a level-long combo,
but you shall first humbly try to finish the levels
without falling in deadly spikes or getting burned in lava!

now, what people expect from a review:

GRAPHICS: cool, a little bit generic and not really varied,
but you won't really focus on it.

MUSIC: very cool, gets you really in the mood of skating,
some music have a rythm that can very close to the game rythm,
leading to moments where your actions are synced with the music,
just by chance. also, no dubsteb. so really cool.

LIFETIME:
pretty much time, from 10 hours if you want to go straight,
to 35-50 hours if you want to 100% the game.
(I played OlliOlli 1, so started with an advantage)

BONUS: MULTIPLAYER.

the game has a local splt-screen multiplayer, which is really great,
but as you need minimum 1 hour of practice before not slamming
your face on the road every 2 meters, it's not a game i would play
with my friends,  it's sadly not immediatly fun.
(but really fun with a minuimum of practice!)

TO OLLIOLLI 1 OWNERS:
More graphics, more music, more tricks, more difficulty.
buy it.

LINUX:
the game's available on Linux. pretty cool.
so if you are a linux user, first, I respect you,
secondly, buy this game.
(if you didn't played Portal 1/2, Super Meat Boy and  VVVVV, though)


TL;DR:
read the first five lines of my review, and  buy the game.
11/10 would beat world records in RAD mode again.

Come on, buy the game, I need people playing this game,
I have world records on almost every levels, I need new challengers!

reviewText:
Fantastic game for score-attack lovers like myself. I loved the skating mechanics with the easy to learn hard to master" feel that these kinds of games often have. Many tracks (especially in the 2nd and 4th worlds) featured branching paths that offer rewards (or death).

SOME GRIPES:
1) DO NOT buy this game if you don't have a controller. This game was NOT made w/ keyboard and mouse in mind.
2) The game is surprisingly short. In roughly 5 hours I managed to beat all 5 worlds. I suppose some replayability comes from five-staring levels (which unlocks PRO versions of the levels
date: and eventually RAD versions) but after a certain point
recommended: star objectives become quite obnoxious...\n\nCONCLUSION: Fantastic if you like score-attack games and have a controller. Wait for a sale
voteText: January 26

reviewText:
Overall a lot of fun! 8.5/10

I never played the first OlliOlli*

OlliOlli2 has  SKATE (EA)  like challegnes throughout the levels.  ex.  score 500,000 * do a x40 combo, etc
It is a very fun little game. I've played about 3.5 hrs and will contiune to roll through the challenges.  It has a really good pace.

Beat all challenges on an amatuer-level and it unlocks the respective Pro-level. Beat all Pro-level challenges and it unlcoks RAD mode. Which im assuming is crazy difficult and combo specific.

PROS
The contols feel tight.
The game has a one button level reset, so its fast to try and re-try.
2D eliminates the frustrating 3D aspect of SKATE and T. HAWK to 'line up perfectly' for your trick
The challenges are ... challenging.
A daily online challenge with Online Scoreboard (you get to practice and then get only one shot)
Addicting and quick gameplay, where you'll say 1 more try" about 20x

CONS:
Minor menu annoyances
Memory leak?  ive noticed after playing for 30 mins or so
date: the framerate gets choppy. Reset the game and it smooths out. Others report similar.\nI paid $2 extra bucks for the soundtrack
recommended: but its not that great.  I wouldnt reccommend that.\nSome tracks are annoying

Overall GG
